A great start to a great franchise. Can't believe how well the first couple of Half-Life games hold up. The atmosphere in each game is gorgeous, engrossing, and irreplaceable. It's a distinct style that only Half-Life could pull off. I'll miss the veterans who worked on this game; it's clear those lost influences have impacted the direction of modern Half-Life, for better or worse. But I will always be grateful for the world this introduced, and the influence it has had on the games that came after, the developers it spawned. If you can't tell, I really really really like this game. A lot. Play it. I don't think you'll regret it. This is playable history for an entire industry.

[h1]Made the FPS genre better[/h1]
Before Half-Life, the FPS genre had almost non-existent storylines that appeared as a paragraph at the end of episodes like in Wolfenstein 3D, Doom, and Quake outside of being mindless shooters. Half-Life pushes the stereotype by forcing you to use tactics for dealing with your targets as well as solving physics puzzles. To incorporate the story, this game puts you into the mind of Gordon Freeman. Everything you see, Gordon sees. You commute to his job, talk to the scientists, and overheard the soldiers plans while still being Dr. Freeman.

Hello Gordon

Somehow, I missed this classic when it was first released.  I got back onto Steam and thought I should catch up.  Even though I'm only two-thirds of the way through, it's been like a page-turner.  Of course, the textures look primitive now, and there are only about 10 different NPC models, but I don't really notice.  The level design is clever for a linear story line -- some puzzles require you to backtrack to make sure you didn't miss anything the first time through.  I especially like how each weapon type is suited for different purposes.  Obviously, if you're new to first-person shooters, you have to play this game, but even if you're a veteran, play this to appreciate how Half-Life influenced many FPSes to follow.

TREMENDO, si eres fan de la acción y ciencia ficción Half-Life es un titulo que deberías probar sobre todo si estas comenzando en esto del gaming y gustas probar títulos del estilo First Person Shooter, el juego te llega a poner en escenarios caóticos donde el peligro asecha en cada esquina, posee ambientes dinámicos e interactivos en los que cada detalle cuenta y con ello tendrás que pensar en como usarlos a tu favor para lidiar con las distintas situaciones a las que te enfrentas, y lo mejor de todo no necesitas de una PC de alto rendimiento para poder disfrutar del juego tu computadora puede ser una tostadora y lo correrá ademas de que puedes seguir disfrutando del mismo aun después de terminar su campaña principal gracias a su modo multijugador.

Incluso a este día sigue siendo un excelente juego y una obra maestra en su época. Después de varios años de escuchar alabanzas y el ansiado regreso de la serie con Half Life Alyx (VR solamente para mi desgracia que no cuento con un headset) me decidí a comprarlo en las rebajas de Steam. Que increíble juego la verdad no parece que hayan pasado 22 años desde que salió. Este juego es la prueba de que un clásico bien desarrollado y con gran diseño de niveles perdura por siempre. Tiene fallas como cualquier otro juegode la época o incluso hoy en día; como un sistema de salto un poco incómodo de utilizar, el personaje suele atascarse en ciertos lugares por alguna razón y un sistema de autoguardado que podría ser complementado con una selección de niveles para jugarlos después o en mi caso no tener munición para seguir avanzando, esta última puede llevar a situaciones muy frustrantes en dificultad difícil y no recomendaría confiar en ese autoguardado. Sin embargo, de alguna manera se compensa con guardado manual en cualquier punto. Como conclusión si tienen una cuenta de Steam no existe una razón por la que no tengan este juego. MUY recomendado.

(No spoilers, and this is an actual review intended for those not familiar with Half-Life)

This game was revolutionary, and a must-play for anyone who is interested in video game history. That said, I think the point of Steam reviews is more about if the game is worth playing on its own merits, and imo this one hasn't really held up super well. There's some things that are still great in modern day, like the atmosphere and sound design (although the actual sound quality is about what'd you expect from the game's era). However, to be honest, I don't think those just looking for a game to have fun in and don't really care about history and 'playing the first Half-Life' and such will get much out of this.

This game has some serious flaws, some of which I've heard even the most die-hard fans acknowledge, and others that apparently are a hot take from me for whatever reason. I think most people agree that the last two chapters are pretty lackluster in terms of level design, as well as some other bits throughout. In general, this game has a lot of 'where the hell am I supposed to go' moments, which can be pretty frustrating, though I can forgive that since to be completely honest I am the sort of person who gets easily lost in both games and real life. (In other words your mileage may vary)

I think the gunplay is this game is generally pretty crappy by modern standards. And I don't mean crappy as in just mediocre, like in Half-Life 2, I mean actually annoyingly bad. My most hated weapon in particular is the MP5 (or the M4 if you're using the HD pack [which don't by the way because it sucks]). Every bullet seems to go left or right and anywhere but what you're aiming at, and not like in Counter Strike or other games where it's an actual pattern you can control. It's just basically unusable, which sucks since you kinda have to use it unless you want to have a very hard time getting through certain sections. Only a few of the weapons have any power to them, due to floaty, dated looking animations. 

The AI is generally pretty good, a bit too good aim-wise in my opinion. You can get pixel-sniped in this game pretty easily, which is especially annoying during some of surface sections. Other than this though you will definitely feel like you're fighting formidable foes throughout the game. Soldiers especially have very complicated scripting in certain areas that make them behave more like real-life soldiers. They will flank, lob grenades, and get to cover to gain the upper-hand. The AI is overall is challenging, but mostly fair.

As many will say and I will agree with is that this game is world-class in storytelling and atmosphere. It starts very slow, setting up the world and events that play, before thrusting you into survival-scavenge mode. I don't have many criticisms here, except that a more robust 'level' (or chapter) select probably would have been helpful, like was done in the sequel. The game generally keeps you immersed very well, with an optional but fairly helpful tutorial level. 

This is a minor nitpick, but I'm generally not a big fan of games have a quicksave feature over more optimal checkpoints, as personally it takes me out of the world because I'm worrying about whether I should save now or wait or whatever. Also, the voice acting, while very funny and something I love to quote to friends, is kinda bad. It's not really the voice actors as much as it's the writing; again though it's pretty funny and honestly one of the parts of the game I cherish. 

In summary, while the game definitely is very important and has very real high points, I don't think someone who doesn't already have an alternative motivation to get through the game is likely to enjoy it nearly as much as people like to say. If you've never played a Half-Life game, to be honest I would recommend skipping this one and its expansions, and just start at Half-Life 2. The sequel is a much better all-around game, and retcons a lot of stuff anyways so it doesn't matter that much to be out of the loop. If you're into older games and somehow haven't played this however, you may be into it.

I'm not usually into FPS games. Every single one is the same: you're a military dude, running around in a big open map with all your friends shooting other military dudes. If you shoot enough of them, you win.

This game is the opposite of that. The story is well-crafted. The graphics are quite appealing for how old they are. and it's quite fun to play. The one downside is the difficulty, though you can get past anything with enough attempts.

So much has been said about this game that it hardly feels worth even reviewing, but in spite of the fact that I've been immersed in Half-Life lore and fandom from a young age as a PC gamer and FPS fan, it's only been recently that I've actually picked up the game and played it, so please consider this a review for the benefit of people who may have heard a lot about Half-Life but just haven't gotten around to it yet.

The one thing that everyone praises about this game above all else is the way that it seamlessly marries story and gameplay, and I have to say it lives up to the hype.  The game is well-structured and paces itself so that the story unfolds at around the same pace that the mechanics do.  It all flows pretty naturally, beginning with Gordon Freeman as a humble scientist and following him as he adapts to a bizarre situation and becomes something much bigger than he was before, and this whole time the level design organically teaches you the game's basic mechanics and encourages you to use them to get better at the game at your own pace, so you never feel like you're being left behind but it also never feels like you're having your hand held either.  The story is rarely if ever intrusive, meaning that you can enjoy the depth of Half-Life's story at your leisure if you please or you can just treat it like a fun shooter and ignore the story entirely.  It's up to you.

The gameplay isn't without its quirks.  There's a lot more platforming than one would expect, a product of the age in which Half-Life was developed.  If you're not accustomed to platforming in first-person it may take some getting used to.  Crouch-jumping also doesn't feel quite as smooth as it is in more modern games, but with practice you'll get the hang of it.  There were only one or two moments where the platforming felt intrusive and out-of-place and they were generally short enough to be forgiven.

Some friends I've spoken to take umbrage with the inventory system in Half-Life, preferring the more conventional weapon-swapping system in which you use the scroll wheel to cycle through weapons, whereas here the scroll wheel cycles through a menu that you have to pick a weapon from.  At first this seems like a bizarre choice even for the time, but on reflection I actually quite like this system, because it adds an extra second of panic when you're trying to swap weapons in combat and that works really well with the story.  Gordon Freeman is not a trained soldier, he's a scientist who happens to have a suit of power armor on; he's not trained to deal with the stress of combat and that's reflected in that extra second of clunkiness you'll get when you switch weapons.  Sure it's not the smoothest design, but Gordon isn't a smooth fighter, at least not until the events of Half-Life 2 when he's got more combat experience under his belt.

If you absolutely must play this game unspoiled then you can stop reading here assured that I thoroughly recommend Half-Life as a classic shooter with an excellent narrative focus and solid gameplay that still holds up today.  Give it a download, play it through, hunt for some secrets, download some mods, play the Deathmatch mode, have fun.  It's well-worth the ten bucks Valve is charging for it these days and it's certainly worthy of your time.



So spoiler time then: I hate this game.  I'm serious, I fucking hate this game.  Specifically I hate the last few levels, after Gordon teleports to Xen.  If you have friends that played Half-Life you've probably heard them say that the Xen levels are terrible and they really are.  I was having a ton of fun shooting zombies, sneaking around military personnel and alien invaders, and letting the levels challenge me to figure out the best solutions myself in real time.  Then Xen happened, and the entire dynamic of the game changed.  Lower gravity, heavier emphasis on platforming, more numerous and increasingly annoying enemies, really difficult to find ammo, confusing level design, and a constant sense that you have no idea what the game wants from you.

To be clear, I think I would have liked Xen if the game had done a better job of setting it up, but as it stands it comes right out of nowhere and leaves me utterly gobsmacked at how fundamentally opposed to the core design of Half-Life it really is.  I think I know what they were going for: Xen is supposed to be the point where Gordon steps into an utterly unknown world and has to survive on his wits and intuition, but instead what it feels like is my asshole friends stopped Highlander right towards the climax and put Highlander 2 in instead.  And then punched me in the gut.

I was so utterly repulsed by Xen and so frustrated with how bullshit the enemies and level design were at this point in the game that I actually stopped playing.  I will never finish Half-Life.  Why should I?  The game's ending is plastered all over YouTube and the sequel has been out since 2007.  I know what happens, and I know that there's a better game in my library waiting for me to play it.  Why would I waste my time with this crap?

Despite all of my revulsion for the penultimate chapters of the game, however, my recommendation stands, because at its core Half-Life is still a five out of five classic shooter with a well-deserved reputation as an innovator in the market which the industry continues to use as a design template to this day.  It just so happens that right towards the end its five star score to drops down to a two star.  I know that's harsh but I'm trying to give an honest review based on my experience with the game.  Maybe you won't find the Xen levels as offensive as I did and that's fine with me; do enjoy them at your leisure, but you've been warned.
